description.topic: Automated Analytic Essay Scoring and Feedback Generation.
description.supervisor: Paula Buttery, Andrew Caines, and Øistein Andersen.
description.funding: fully funded by the Cambridge ALTA Institute, supported by Cambridge University Press & Assessment.

description.topic: Multi-task Learning for Analytic Automated Essay Scoring.
description.award: Wolfson College Jennings Prize for outstanding academic accomplishments (£300).

description.dissertation: Elliptic Cryptography (with the School of Mathematics).

description.options: with Further Mathematics, Ancient Greek and L3 Japanese.
description.grade: Distinction (19.92/20); top student of my specialisation.

work.name: TechWolf
work.summary: Interned in the Research team of this HR Tech scale-up company which uses AI&ML to offer insights into the skills of a company's workforce. My work focused on automatically growing the company's ontology of skills, an in-house dictionary of unique skills which sits at the very core of their product, as new industries emerge.

description.project: fine-tuned a pre-trained language model on a dataset of 1000 sentences that I labelled myself. The resulting IOB-labelling model helped discover new skill spans from free text. Once extracted, these were compared and matched to those already present in the company's ontology, using embedding cosine similarity. For any new (unmatched) skill, I automatically generated potential synonymous forms using traditional parsing methods and WordNet.
description.research: deep literature review in the fields of Psychology, Economics and HR, to help formalise the company's definition of skill.

work.name: Microsoft
work.summary: A 12-week remote internship with the FAST CAR Team working with the Contacts & People Relationships APIs for Office 365.

description.project: designed, implemented, and tested a C# mailbox processor to extract social-media accounts from a user's personal emails, infer the owners of the accounts, and add the data to that user's Contacts.
description.documentation: actively expanded the team's onboarding and technical documentation; I was praised for the quality of my work.
description.hacking: volunteered in company-wide hackathon for the charity DigiGirlz and helped prototype, implement, and pitch a Unity Game to teach basic networking principles to young girls.
description.networking and cooperation: in a remote context, I had to quickly learn the expertise of different individuals/teams and managed to coordinate people from far and wide to get the project done in time.

work.name: J.P. Morgan & Chase
work.summary: The internship was shortened, and made remote due to COVID-19.

description.group project: designed, implemented and demoed a Python Django web application for care-experienced young people, providing a tech solution to the challenges the Scottish charity MCR Pathways was facing due to COVID-19. Learned about and followed Agile principles.
description.training: was assessed in weekly coding tasks that were reviewed by my manager who provided high-quality feedback and mentorship.

work.name: Taskize Limited
work.summary: First hired under the COO's supervision for marketing tasks, my role broadened greatly as the internship progressed.

description.development: expanded the company's Python API and used it to generate scenarios for client demonstration purposes, and developed a simple Python app (using Tkinter) to speed-up client on-boarding.
description.front-end design: built a mock-up website to present some ideas for a new company website, and maintained the existing website.
description.content creation: learned to use the Camtasia video editing software, and eventually produced three full videos for the company website.

work.name: MeditSimple
work.summary: Two week internship in a start-up whose mission was to create the first common virtual space for doctors and patients in Europe.

description.community management: managed the company's social media channels via Buffer, created a series of animated advertising videos using Vyond, wrote blog articles and managed SEOs for Wordpress, collaborated with the development team to test and debug website.

description.options: with Further Mathematics, Ancient Greek and L3 Japanese.
description.grade: Distinction (19.92/20); top student of my specialisation.

awards.title: Best Insight (Honorable Mention)
awards.summary: ASA DataFest is a data analysis competition where teams of up to five students attack a large and complex surprise dataset over a weekend to find and communicate insights into the data. For this competition the Rocky Mountain Poison and Drug Safety Center was interested in discovering and identifying patterns of drug use, with particular attention paid to identifying misuse.

publications.name: Zur Elektrody/namik bewegter Körper
publications.summary: It concerned an interpretation of the Michelson–Morley experiment and the properties of light and time. Special relativity incorporates the principle that the speed of light is the same for all inertial observers regardless of the state of motion of the source.

publications.name: Über einen die Erzeugung und Verwandlung des Lichtes betreffenden heuristischen Gesichtspunkt
publications.summary: In the second paper, he applied the quantum theory to light to explain the photoelectric effect. In particular, he used the idea of light quanta (photons) to explain experimental results, but stressed the importance of the experimental results. The importance of his work on the photoelectric effect earned him the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1921.

publications.name: Die Grundlage der allgemeinen Relativitätstheorie
publications.summary: The publication of the theory of general relativity made him internationally famous. He was professor of physics at the universities of Zurich (1909–1911) and Prague (1911–1912), before he returned to ETH Zurich (1912–1914).

projects.name: Quantum Computing
projects.summary: Quantum computing is the use of quantum-mechanical phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to perform computation. Computers that perform quantum computations are known as quantum computers.
